div.head: Votre Sang Est-Il Parfaitement Pur?
div.p: Une condition essentielle pour que l'organisme soit toujours en parfaite santé, c'est de tenir notre corps dans le plus grand état de propreté, non pas seulement a l'extérieur mais aussi interieurement.
Quand, en effet, le sang s'epaissit ou s'appauvrit, il en resulte de bien tristes maladies :
Scrofule, Affections de la Peau, Anémie, &c.

Il faut donc nettoyer, purifier le sang et puis l'enrichir; pour cela, rien de meilleur que l'Emulsion Scott, faites-en usage et beintôt, comme les brumes matinales devant les rayones du soleil, se dissiperont tous les maux dont vous êtes affligés !
L'EMULSION SCOTT
PURIFIE; RÉGÉNÈRE; FORTIFIE.
En vente chez tous Pharmaciens et Droguistes.
Exigez toujours l'Emulsion avec cette marque : "le Pécheur", marque du procédé Scott !

MONDAY, AUGUST 6, 1906.

div.head: TRIPOLI, FRANCE. AND THE SULTAN
div.p: Tripoli is so near Egypt that any attempts ot the Sultan to increase his power there is of considerable interest to us. With regard to the question of the oasis of Djanet, whether the Turkish Government has despatched Captain Abdul Kader with forty men, the Porte declares that the territory is Turkish, being a portion of the vilayet of Tripoli, and that a holy flag is preserved at Djanet, whose inhabitants pay taxes to the Turkish authorities. The Frenoh Embassy at Constantinople presented a Note last week declaring that Djanet was recognised as French territory by the Anglo Frenoh agreement, and warning the Porte of the dangerous consequences of main taining troops there. To this Note, according to Renter's telegram of Saturday, the Porte has replied maintaining her olaim to Djanet as an integral portion of the vilayet of Tripoli Djanet is due west of Assouan.

The French have a great problem before them in their vast land-locked Empire in the centre of Africa. With remarkable energy and success they have gradually brought more of the provinces in their sphere of action under control, but the vital question of how to utilize them after the conquest is one which most cause considerable anxiety for a long time to come. Owing to difficulties of access they are likely to be as valuable as oolonies in the moon. Tripoli is still, and is likely to remain for some time, the best route to the new Frenoh empire. The greatest problem which France has to face is the finding of means of communication and an outlet for possible trade. Sokoto, Bornu, and Bigirmi are in a fair way towards being settled, but Wadai remains to be conqaerel. Whichever way they tarn Frenchmen are faced with thousands of miles ot semi desett, dotted only with occasional oases and almost impossible caravan routes through the belt ot the Great Sahara. For a century Tripoli haa been the best and most praotioal opening for trade with the oentre of Africa, for the methods of communicating through Algiers and Tania present apparently insurmountable difficulties. The oaravan routes from Tripoli are practicable, and with very little trouble could be improved. The 'Parks have never attempted to exercise an active power in Central Africa, confining themselves within their most southern boundary of Fezzan ; bat geographically and through the complete monopoly of trading relations the Hinterlands of Tripoli, including Bornu, Bagirmi, and Wadai, certainly fall to the Sultan. These rights were, of course, ignored by both Great Britain and France when the Convention of 1899 was signified, and the protests of the Saltan of Tarkey went unheeded.

Furthermore, the scheme of capturing the trade of Central Africa and diverting it from the Tripoli route to Tunis has been another of France's ambitions, for the oaravans pass temptingly close to the Tunisian frontier via Ghadames and Ghat on their way to Bornu and the Western Sadan. It is almost oertaio that a few years ago the Frenoh intended to take in Ghadames, which is a wealthy centre of Arab caravan traders and so tear the frontier as easily to be made a matter of dispute. For no reason which could be justified by the military necessity of paoitying Tunis, the French very quietly established a strong military base at the extreme south of Tonis in Gabes, this town being selected because it possesses excellent water, a rarity in this dry country. Large barracks and hospitals were built and vast stores collected, all being very nnostentatioasly brought with the troops by the regular steamers from Marseilles. No doubt whatever was felt in Tripoli about the intention of the French to seize some portion of it at least, and the Italians themselves were extremely nervous and anxious. They went to the length of picking a qaarrel with the Governor of Benghazi as though to look for compeQsatiou in that direction.

Meanwhile the Sultan became seriously alarmed. With astonishing celerity he despatched steamer after steamer to Tripoli with men and stores, and it was compnted by the Consulat authorities there that in a very few months at least 30,000 Tarkish soldiers had been landed and for the most part immediately hurried off to the Tunisian frontier. ' New forts were bailt, the old ones were repaired, and the harbour of Tripoli was proteo'ed by torpedoes. For some months the Tarkish and Frenoh troops faoed each other at the frontier, and many little Rcidents occurred which could easily have been made the cause of a qaarrel; but the astute diplomacy of the then Governor-General, Rassim Pasha, warded off a corfiiet. For months the position was extremely strained. Measures were being taken in the town of Tripoli itself with a view to protecting the Christians against the rising anger of the Moslem population. But the Turkish position was too strong. The French coaid not master more than 10,COO troops to meet the 30,000 Turks, who were by no means the andis-o plined horde the French had had to deal with under the Bey of Tunis. France was evidently not prepared or inolined to undertake an expedition on a large scale, and a joint commission was appointed to delimitate the frontiers, and the incident ended. The oamp Gabes was declared unhealthy, and the French troops were gradually withdrawn. Evidence of this abortive soheme ia still to be seen in the empty barracks at Gabea. Bat the ambition to captare the trade with Central Africa still lingers, and many studies were made from Gabes with a view to diverting he trade from Tripoli. Oae of these schemes endei in the fatal termination of the career of the somewhat fanatical Marquis de Morbs, who, while attempting to penetrate into the inferior from Gabes, was murdered only a few days' march inland by the tribe of the Chaamba. It is evident that the French wilkhe obliged to establish some means of commnnioation with the Mediterranean coast if they are to benefit by their Central African colonies, through Beughaz: from Wadai and throngh Tanis, failing Tripoli, from Bornu and the Western SudaD. What there may be in the unpublished part of the Franco-Italian agreement, or what understanding may have been arrived at regarding the fature working of the caravan trade with Italy, we do not yet know ; in any case neither ooantry has an enviable task before it. And judging from the news in the telegram the Sultan has taken up a firm stand against all suoh pretensions.

div.head: Hashish Seizure.
div.p: On the 28th alt., the Coast Guards confiscated 183 kilos of hashish at Um el Kish, near bmailia.

div.head: Sudan Crops.
div.p: The crops are reported to be benefiting greatly by the rains which fell lately at Wad-Medani and Ehartoam.

div.head: Business Announcement.
div.p: Dr. Arbeely, surgeon dentist, has just returned to Cairo and is ready for business from today (Monday), 6th inst.

div.head: Brigandage.
div.p: The enquiry into the case of brigandage at Burn having been concluded, the trial will come before the local magistrate.

div.head: Pharmacy Regulations.
div.p: The ''Journal Official" publishes a list of persons who have been condemned by the Tribunals for breach 36 of the Pharmacy Regulations.

div.head: Moulld at Belbels.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has given permission for the moulid of Sheikh Mohamed Alouan to be held at Eelbeis from the 2nd to 9tb inst

div.head: A strange Rumour.
div.p: It is rumoured that Mustapha Pasha Kamel has become a German subject. We have been unable, however, to obtain any confirmation of this news.

div.head: Khartoum Bridge.
div.p: The construotion of Khartoum Bridge has been postponed indefinitely for financial reasons. This bridge is to join the two portions of the city.

div.head: Anglo-Belgian Co. of Egypt
div.p: The Committee of the London Stock Exchange has fixed Aug. 9 as a special settling day in Anglo Belgian Company of Egypt. Ltd.— 70,000 shares of £5 each, fully paid, Nos. 1 to 70,0C0.

div.head: Drowning Fatalities.
div.p: The body of the Frenchman who was drowned last week in the Nile eff Kasr-el-Nil has not yet been reooverel That of a native who perished at El Ramla has been found, and has since been buried.

div.head: less Majeete.
div.p: The policeman who tore up a copy of the "Egyptian Gazette" at Tantah station and assaulted Abd-el-Radi, the vendor of our newspaper there, has been sentenced by the Native Court at Tantah to a pay a fine and the costs of the case, the total amounting to £10.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The landslip-disaster which for a time closed the Cenisio national highway and railway, has been remedied, and the Paris-Lyons Mediterranean Railway is again running through trains to Italy. Last week's Brindisi mail, however, had to go via the Simplon route to London.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: This evening, Sig. Novelli's company will present Brieux's new 3-act comedy Gli Ava-riati (Les Avaries), which, according to the author's description, is "a severe study of the consequences of the indiscretions of youth," etc. The comedy has met with considerable success in France.

div.head: Ban Stefano Casino.
div.p: The feat organised yesterday in aid of the Russian refugees in Egypt was an immense SUCCESS, the casino being thronged with people al1 day and the arrangements being carried out to the satisfaction of all. The winning numbers in the lottery were as follows : — 5,178 ; 10,204 ; 8,153; 8,985 ; 6,307 ; 877 ; 19,509. Boa Wood.

After a northerly wind the shores of Alexandria are strewn with masses of sea weed which, thrown up by the waves, form into hummooks along the beach, to the great annoyance of bathers and trippers. Could not this weed be removed, and made use of in much the same way as the Japanese do 1 asks a correspondent. Either as manure, or as stuffing for mattresses, the weed might be adapted to the service of rather than annoyance of a suffering community. In Japan the seaweed crop yields an annual revenue of £'00,000.

div.head: New Employment Registry.
div.p: The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: Instrumental Concerts
div.p: Every Night on the Verandah of the Windsor Hotel, Alexandria from 6 to 12 P.M. 5 O'clock Tea served on Verandah.

CARLTON HOTEL. Bulkeley (near Alexandria.) Halfway to san Stefano Ramleh's Fashionable Hotel Patronised by the Elite. Full Pension P.T. 50 a day. Visitors from Cairo alight at Sidi-Gaber station. 24.11.06 C. Aquilina, Proptietor.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: Arrival at Kissingen
A Reuter's telegram to-day states thatH.H. the Khedive has arrived at Kissingen, in Bavaria.

div.head: THE DENISHWAI AFFAIR.
div.p: It is announced that three of the seven participants in the Denishwai outrage who disappeared were recently captured by the police, and that the authorities are in communication in regard to their trial. It is stated that in consequence of the prompt justice exeouted in the Denishwai case there is quite a movement among well-to-do natives to become subjects of foreign Powers!

div.head: FANATICAL OUTBREAK.
div.p: A Santa correspondent writes that a demonstration against the Christians was made last week at the village of Sonnonres, Fayoum, by mobs of Moslems, who paraded the streets, brandishing nabouts, and with the cry of "Kill or convert" raided the Greek and Coptic shops, and maltreated the shopkeepers. The police intervened in time to check the development of the outbreak, and an enquiry is proceeding. This riot may probably have been due to the conversion of a sheikh to Coptic Christianity. "Al Mokattam" learns that a few days ago some low-class Moslems ot Akhmin, in Upper Egypt, attacked a Coptic funeral in that town and threw stones at the mourners. The aggressors were arrested by the markaz authorities, who have opened an inquiry into the oiroom-stances of the case.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: El Miralai R. C. R. Owen Bey, having completed his term of service with the Egyptian Army, has been struck off the strength. El Bimbaehi A. C. Jeff coat, D S.O., of the 10th Sudanese, has similarly been strnok off the strength of the Egyptian Army. His Highness the Khedive has been most graciously pleased to approve of the promotions of temporary Kaimakams S K. Flint Bey and C. McKay Bey,respectively assistant direotor of stores and assistant director of Cnstoms in the Sudan Government, to the full rank of Kaima-kam. El Bimbasbi F. W. Woodward, D.S 0., has been transferred from his service in the Upper Nile District to the 10th Sudanese Battalion. Lieutenant H. F. 0. Thwaites, Royal Engineers, who recently arrived in Egypt, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army with the rank of Bimbashi. He is posted to the Department of Works. Leave of absence has been granted to the nndermentioned officials as follows :— El Miralai Mahmond Bey Tanfik, director of the Military School, nntil September 23 ; El Miralai Bond Bey, D.SO, director of steamers and boats, until October 9; El Kaimakam Cummins Bey, MB., Afsdical Corps, until 1 October 10; El Bimbashi Bethell, Artillery, until September 26 ; El Bimbaehi Wise, Camel Corps, nntil September ; El Bimbashi Rome, Cavalry, until September30; El Bimbashi Edgeworth, assistant direotor of works, until the 10th inst. BI Miralai Hawker Bey, Governor of the Red Sea province, resnmed his functions on the 1st inst. El Bimbashi Johnson, assistant director of stores, has been granted extension of leave until the 28th inst.

div.head: RECRUITING REGULATIONS.
div.p: The following grievance has been brought to onr notice. It appears to be justified The regulations providing exemption from military service are very hard on the candidates attending the secondary schools. The regulations provide the exemption of the students attending Al Azhar even tor three years whereas a pnpil who ha3 completed his primary coarse of study in four years and joined the secondary schools does not enjoy the same privilege, although he ought to be similarly privileged.

div.head: UNION FONCIERE D'EGYPTE.
div.p: This company has recently made some very pn fitable sales of land. 130 feddans at Dar el-Bakar were sold for L.E. 10,000, which were originally pnrehafed at a rata of L.E. 35 per feddan. The company has also lately purchased 400 feddans at L.E. 45 per feddaD, which are worth at least L.E. 60 in their present state.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: The Railway Administration is drawing up a special tariff for the transport of goods belonging to the Socidtd des Sncreries et Raftinerie d'Egypte, as per the clauses of the contract of cession to the Administration of the railways owned by the company.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Yesterday's plague bulletin* records a fresh oase at Suez To-day, a fatal case is reported at Alexandria, the victim being a native boy living in the Labbane quarter.

div.head: EGYPTIAN PRESS
div.p: MR. FINDLAY'S CHARGES

The charges of bribery brought by Mr. Mansfield de C. Findlay in his telegram to Sir E. Grey against the section of the European and vernacular press which did not hold the same views as the British Agency in regard to the Denishwai affair, are thus commented on by "Al Moayad" :— The British Diplomatic Agency appears to have gone into the Denishwai affair with definite political ends in view. One was to stop Parliament having any voice in Egyptian affairs, and the other was to suppress the liberty of the Egyptian press. What could the British Agency answer if it were asked to prove that the newspapers' articles showed that they had received a large sum of money as a subsidy ? Has not the British Agency excited the Egyptian Press by the hue and cry it raised and by charging the whole country with fanaticism for which the Press is held responsible? How can the papers receive bribes for simply defending themselves ? Who is it who laid out this money? Possibly our contemporary, the "Egyptian Gazette," would agree with us if we opine that the recent changes in the plans and policy of England in Egypt have been due to the standpoint which the local Press took up in the Denishwai affair. These opinions of the Press were regarded by Mr. Findlay as severe strictures on the British Administration in Egypt. If our contemporary refuses to accept this view, and Mr. Findlay remains unconvinced of the true facts as indicated by "Al Moayad," then we, in our position as a national representative newspaper, will prove the falseness of the charge of the British Charge d'Affaires and will boldly declare that if anyone makes any insinuations of bribery against "Al Moayad" let him prove it; otherwise, however high be his position, his insinuation must be considered as a falsehood. "Al Lewa" remarks apropos of Mr. Findlay's charges, that this is part of the English policy, to attempt to throw discredit on the native Press and thereby to remove the effects which the outcry these papers made over the Denishwai affair had in London.

div.head: HEAVY RAINS AND WASHOUTS
div.p: Heavy rains have fallen on the Suakin-Atbara line snd wash-outs have taken place in several places. The line has been broken tince the 27th inst., and no trains are leaving jast now either ways, all traffic being stopped for the present. It is hoped the lines will be repaired to morrow. Bimbashi Lord, R.E., is superintending the wash-outs from Gebeit. The line was also interrupted for two days between Suakin and Port Sudan, but is in*working order again. The British steamer Wensleydale arrived from England on the 27th inst. with a special orgo for, the Sudan Railways, inolnding 110 steel bridges and cdlverts for the Port Sudan line., PURIFICATION OF ALEXNDRIA The crusade which Miralai Hopkinson Bey and the Alexandria City Police are waging against immorality in Alexandria is being seconded by the Consulates. The eleven women who were arrested is the city last week, on the charge of leading an indecorous life, have been summoned before their Consols, who warned them against going for walks in the neighbourhood of Mohamed Aly-rquare in the evening. If they are again observed nootnrnally perambulating they will he sent home to their native lands. All the women undertook to comply with the wishes of the police. Two women, who are believed not be respectable, were arrested last night in company with a European man as they were piomenading in the streets, and despatched to the Italian Consulate.

div.head: CAIRO POLICE.
div.p: With reference to a report published in thfl "Egyptian Gszette" of the 27th ultimo headed "Our Berbereen," it appears that the facts of the case are as follows:— Policemen No. 1131, who was on beat duty at Clot Bey street, seeing a disturbance at Atfet E Suk, went to the spot to see what the matter was. He found an Italian named Giovanni Prola and a native coffee-shop keeper quarrelling, and a knife in the former's hand. He called ghaffir No. 7, and both took the Italian and native to the oaraool, where a proefes verbal was drawn up against them for brawling. The chief points elioited by the evidence are:— (l) That the policeman was not present when the affair began (according to the Italian and his witnesses, they never saw him at all); (2) The Italian is not more than 40 years of age, and is not the proprietor of the land, which belongs to a Copt who looks alter it for his mother ; (3) There is no evidence of the ghaffir striking the Italian; (4) There were no Berbereen present, or at the most there was only one; (5) The "Frenchman" who interfered is known by sight, Oddly and is believed to have been a Qresk. The orderly r fiber who drew up the procks verbal made a note in same to the effeot that the European said to have been attacked was slightly drunk.

div.head:
THE SOHAG TRAGEDY
How Mr. Horton Met His Death
div.p: Last Friday we published a telegram from a Sohag correspondent reporting the death of Mr. George Hortoh, an inspector of the Sleeping Car Company, whose head was cut off while the train on which he was travelling was passing under Kanafi Bridge. From inquiries which we have made, and from the inquest which was held on Saturday morning at the German Hospital by Mr. A. D. Alban, we have elicited the facts connected with deceased's terrible death, which are as follows :— On Thursday, Mr. Hortob left Luxor by the 5.30 p.m. train in charge of the sleeping and restaurant cars. There being but few passengers, the deceased, after dinner, went to the roof of the car, where he sat for some time by himself. It appears that he was aconstomed to travel in this way. Somewhat later he invited Gastave Frohman, maltre d'hotel, to join him on the roof, remarking that to travel in snob a position was most pleasant. Deceased was joined by Frohman, who sat on the top step of the ladder, the former being upon the roof of the sleeping car facing the engine. After remaining there some time Frohman complain-ed of the dost, which, he said, blinded him, and went back to the dining-car to get the dost out of his eyes. On returning to join deceased he found that he had changed from the sleeping to the dining oar q^d was sitting with his back to the engine. Mr. Hortob and Frohman then sat side by side, and on reaohing Kanafi Bridge the latter felt something strike his left ear. He bent his he id and Bext saw Mr. Hortob tumbling down head over heels. Frohman desoended to inform the conductor of the sleeping oar, and on arriving at 8ohag, which is only twj kilometres distant from the scene of the accident, they returned on a pilot engine and fonnd that the greater part of Hortob's head was severed from his body, which was removed to the Sohag hospital, where the procks-verbal was drawn np. On the following day the body was removed to Cairo, where the inquest was held on Saturday at the German Hospital. The body was identified by Mr. Garriok, a fiiend of the deceased, and Mr. Chaker, chief controller of the company, and permission for bnrial was given, though the inquest was adjourned until Monday in order to take the evidence of Frohman. The body was interred the same morning. Mr. Hortob leaves a widow, who, we regret to say, will be left in very needy oiron instances on aoooont of the terrible death of her husband. We would, therefore, give prominence to the fact that the company are asking for donations in aid of Mrs. Hortob ander these distressing cironmstanoes. Both deceased and his widow are of English nationality, and we hope that the necessary support will be promptly forthcoming. Donations should be addressed to the Cairo office of the Sleeping Car Company, at the station.

div.head:
THE SULTAN
AMERICAN OPINION.
div.p: The ' New York Evening Mail" remarks :— Lately our ministry to Brazil was raised to the grade of an embassy, as a compliment to that country. We maintain an ambassador to Mexico for maoh the same reason. Partly this, and partly in order that our representative may not be outranked in either of those American countries by the diplomatic agent of any foreign power. But it is not as a compliment that we have made onr minister to Turkey an ambassador. Of conrse it pasres as a distinguished honour, but the motive is really qaite the reverse. Every six months or so the Ottoman Saltan has to he bullied about something. Force is the only international argument that he appreciates. Pressure has to be applied to him by the representative of tha country that has business with himj and it is most snooessfally applied by the agent who has the right to walk into the Saltan's presence. Ambassadors porsess this right: ministers and envoys have the privilege only by the sovereign's invitation or permission. Mr. Leishman, our representative at the Sublime Porte, is a good Snltan-balldozai, bat he has laboured under the disadvantage of being a mere minister. Congress has made him an ambassador. Now he will be a better ball-dizer than ever, for he can walk into the Saltan's private office and say, "See here, yonr sublime and ineffable imperial majesty, it is up to yon to do thus and so." Naturally the Saltan does not appreciate the honour done him in making our minister an ambassador. But if we oorreotly apprehend the character of Mr. Leishman, he will make an early call upon Abdul Hamid jast the same, and will gently but firmly convince him that no other course is open to him. When Uncle Sam decides to honour a Saltan somewhere, that Saltan may as well make up his mind to be honoured.

div.head:
MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL
HIS VISIT TO LONDON
EXTRAORDINARY SECRETARY
div.p: A most strange secrecy appears to have been kept in regard to Mustapha Pasha Kamel's lunch at the Carlton Hotel. The "Daily Express," for instance, remarks : In the course of the four-and-twenty hours which ended at midnight yesterday, and at a hotel or other publio resort within a hundred miles of Charing Cross, there was held a meeting, conversation, or dinner, at which a number of gentlemen, most of whose names we are totally unable to give, met that eminent person Kamel Pasha. We regret being compelled to put this absorbing item of news before onr readers in such a form, as we are conscious that the report lacks precision, but such extraordinary precautions seem to have been taken to ensure secrecy that we cannot do otherwise. It is true an "official" report of the proceedings was issued —but then it is only an "official" report. As it happens, however, the secrecy of the proceedings does not render them less interesting, or, if we may say so, less significant. Yet we are puzzled to account for it. What possible reason can our Little Englander friends have for maintaining secrecy ? It cannot be that they are ashamed of their views, for, as we are aware, they glory in demonstrating to the world how often and how utterly their native country is in the wrong. We oan only suppose that, out of compliment to Kamel Pasha, it was arranged to give the proceedings as much of the air of a little conspiracy as possible. We do not imagine that dreadful things passed at the meeting. It is highly improbable that the guests circulated a oup of blood, after the manner libellonnly imputed to that pre-Canarian Canar, Catiline, and it is even questionable if the green flag was elevated above the Union Jaok amid thunderous cheers for Mahomet. What is more likely is that the missioner of New Egypt was bathed in a congenial atmosphere of "hot air," and that, like the noble animal whose name he bears, the personage of the evening comported himself with much droll dignity. The Kamel of Nationalism has set out on a protracted journey. His ways may be devious, and his goal obscure, but his time cannot be considered to be wholly wasted if he succeeded yesterday in pawing some sand into the eyes ot a small section of the British public. Let ns hope that his futile efforts will give him his namesake's proverbial "hump." The following is the text of the speech of Mr. John M. Robertson, M. P. for Tyneside, of on the occasion of the historio lunoh :— Monsieur le Pacha, Parlant an nom de mes collkgues et compa-triotes, je vou8 assure de I'intkrkt sympathique aveo lequel nous avons entenda votre discoars. Nous cheichons avant tontk nous informer des conditions et des choses de votre pays et nons vonlons, pour cela, entendre les deux odtds. Nons e^pdrons que vos copipatriotes parle-ront toujonrs franchemeut pour nous dire lenrs idkeset leurs plaintes.— Notre idkal est seule-ment de faire le bien de l'Egypte en contrGiant tant que nous avoDS ViDflaence, Padministration gknkrale pendant que nous sommes Ik. A notre avis, le contrdle anglais a beaaooup fait pour les finances kgyptiennes. Nous vonlons faire la mdme pour la vie sooiale, poor l'dducation, poor l'administration et poor la jastice. H ne faut pas que FA ngleterre reste let pour etle meme. Qaant k l'affaire de Denchawai, vons savez bien aveo quelle inquietude on en a re$n les nouvelles ici. Snr cette question, nous ne poa-vons pins rien dire maintenant, tant que nous n'avons pas lu les rapports tffioiels. Maia je puis vons assurer de la sympatbie aotive et sincere d'ane grande partie da people anglais. Nous comprenons bien vos aspirations et nous espdrons toujonrs qu'aveo prudence et deliberation, on verra un jonr s'accomplir l'ideal des Anglais et des Egyptiens : 'TIndk-pen dance garantie de l'Egypte."

div.head: THE AGITATION IN EGYPT.
div.p: The Parisian newspapers publish the following news :— "Le Journal Misr signale plusieurs incidents sarvenas daus la Haute-Egypte entre mnsnl-mans et chrktiens. A Sennourki, les musul-mans on fait nne demonstration dans les mes contre les ohretiens qa'ils ont frappes et dont ils ont ravage les magasins. Les conpahles arrotka ont ete relAohes. On oroit que la police, composke de musnlmans, fait oanse commune aveo les agitatenrs. De graves desordres sont en perspective." A Cairo confrkre remarks : — La Loavelle ci dess ns indique qa'en Europe l'on exploite hahilement, en les exagerant, les bruits d'agitation et de complication qui ont en cours ic;. Nous avons dit et redit que de tontes ces fanfares guerrikres il en fallait prendre et laisser: en prendre un pen et en kisser beanoonp. Cet dchantillon de reclame k rebours que Ton vient de lire, donne olairement a entendre que none sommes an ddbnt d'ane oampagre intdressde qui aura poor idsnltat, si Ton n'y prend garde, de ddgarnir tr£a sensihlement nos hotels, l'hiver ^rochain. * Si l'Egypte est si trouble, allons aillenrs," diront nos visiteurs ordinaires. Et ce seront les antres villes de saison qai pro fi ter ont de l'aobaine. C'est ponrquoi nous orions casse con a ceox qui complaisamment on sans le faire exprka tontlejen de la "ooncoirence." div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H. E. Faad Pasha, Minister of Jastice, is expected to arrive here tomorrow on his return from Europe.
Crookshank Pasha and family have left London for Vittel, in the Vosges district, for the asaal water onre.
Miralai Stanton Bey, Moudir of Khartoum, has returned from leave and has resumed his occupations.
The Porte has accorded the exequator to M. Charles Nicole, a Swiss subject, lately appointed Danish Consul in Egypt.

Mr. R. Draper, who has been appointed assistant controller of ports and lights at Port Sodan, has arrived in Cairo, and is staying at 8hepheard's Hotel. He will leave for Port Sudan via Suez tomorrow.
It is said that Mohamed Bey Tewfik, Sub-Moudir of Ghizsh, will shortly he retired on pension.
Captain C. F. Wilkins, 6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons, and Captain S.G. Roe, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fasiliers, have been granted leave of absence for two months.
Mr. J. H. Grieve, provisionally attached to the Sudan Irrigation Service, has been granted three months leave of absence, to date from July 1.
Mr. Schafer, managing director of the Shannon, Ltd., has arrived in Cairo, and is staying at the Continental Hotel.
Mr. W. F. Sarjeant, the popular assistant manager of the Khedivial Mail Line, returned to Alexandria from leave today by the Austrian steamer.

Mr. E H. Gandy, of Clifford's Inn, London, who has been assistant to Mr. Robert Williams for the last two years in London, has just qualified for his diploma as an architect and A.R.I.B.A. at the Royal Institute of British Architects, and has now joined Mr. Williams as assistant in his growing practice in Egypt This is some compensation to Mr. Williams, who has just lost for a while one of the most apt and hard working of pupils in the person of his young friend, Mr. John Usse, who has had to leave for France for his military training.
Dr. Pris Orom, physioian of the 2nd olass in Port Said Hospital, has retired for reasons of health.
M. Othello Dilogo has been appointed chemist, of the 3rd class, in Kasr el-Aini Hospital.
The names of two Cairenes, M.M. E. Dombre and J. Gerard, are included in the list of commercial advisers published recently in the French "Journal Oflniel."

div.head: EGYPTIAN DELTA LAND AND INVESTMENT COMOANY. LTD.
div.p: The following is the report of the direotors to be presented to the shareholders at the ordinary general meeting to be held on Thurs day, 16th inst.:— Land Purchases.—At the close of the period ended 30th September, 1905, the area of lands purchased aggregate! 479,275 feddans, at a total cost of £127,950, in addition to a one sixth interest in valuable property in the Province of Qharbieh comprising 1,577 feddans. The principal properties are in the neighbourhood of Cairo, Tantah, Behra, and other important towns and villages. During the half-year under review, a farther 30,178 feddans of land have been purchased at a total cost of £4,320 12s. 3d. Also an interest in other properties, consisting of land, building, at a cost of £164,102 Ils. 3d. The total amount of purchases made by the company at 31st March 1906, was £305,990 9s. 7d., on which deferred payments amounting to £104,695 7. 7d. still had to be met. The whole of the purchases made are shown in the balance sheet at cost price plus interest on deferred payments. Development andSales.—The development of our properties has been steadily pushed forward and at the end of March, 1906, the first of the compauy's land sales was held, the results, after allowing for cost of drainage, roads, being in the opinion of the directors most satisfactory. As these sales were held at and after the dose of the half year, and only small amounts on deposit had at that date been received, the results do not appear in the accounts presented. Working Expenses.—The working expenses have been kept at the lowest possible minimum, pending results of sales of lands. The total, inoludiDg direotors' fees, secretary, clerksge, and rent of offices—London and Egypt — amounts to only £887 8s. 8d. Revenue, derived from interest on oash deposits, rents and sales of crops, amount ed to £4,211 18s. 6d., which, after allowing for working and administrative expenses, left a balance of 3,324 9s. lOd. From this was deducted the loss as shewn at 30th September 1905, viz, £779 5s. Od., leaving a nett balance of £2,545 4s. lOi. to be carried forward. As ha9 before been stated, the proceeds of land sales, held at and since the end of March, have not been taken into consideration, but will appear in the next accounts issaed. General —The directors are satisfied that the land purchases which have been made are sound, and steps are being taken to re-open the sales of theproperty at the end of this year when the slack season in Egypt is over. These sale?, it is anticipated, will show considerable profits Vacancy on the Board,—The directors regret to have to record the loss by death of their oolleague Sir Elwin Palmer, K.C.B., K.C.M.G., one of the original directors of this company. Mr. J. W. Williamson has been appointed in his place. Directors.—Sir Auokland Colvin, K.C.S.I, and Baron J. de Menasce retire by rotation, and, being eligible, offer themselves for re-election. Auditors.—The proprietors will be asked to eleot auditors for the ensuing year. The firm of Messrs. Frank Davies, Meredith Co. having divided, the Directors recommend that Messrs. Meredith and Co., who are eligibe, and have offered themselves for eleotion, shall be appointed. The following is the profit and loss aocount from 80th September, 1905, to 31st Meroh 1906. Mar. 31,

div.head: REUTERS' TELEGRAMS.
div.p: CLONING REPORTS

div.head:
RUSSIAN CRISIS.
GENERAL STRIKE BEGUN
MUTINY OF TROOPS.
GOVERNOR KILLED BY BOMB,.

div.p: . A general strike has begon. 15,000 factory hands are already idle. The railway employes here have been ordered to go on strike at midnight to-night and in Mosoow at noop tomorrow.
The Governor of Samara has been killed by a bomb.
Small steamers, carrying quick-firing gnus on the decks, are ornising in the Neva in anti, oipation of labour riots.

It is understood that amongst those who were arrested at Sveaborgand Kronstadt there are some Labour members of the Duma. It is estimated that 600 persons were killed or wounded at Sveaborg.- There are 1,000 missing.

. There are now 55,000 men on strike. The railway strike has been postponed. A mutiny of the troops has tiken place at Dashlager (Transcaucasia). The troops fired a volley at their'officers and killed si* ;and wounded four of them.
Hundreds of factories are idle. The strikers have pillaged Sestrovesk station. Several Jio- lice have been killed or wounded.
The railway employees in the neighbourhood of the city are quiet.

Aftfcongh 55,000 men are on strike here, there are indications that a general strike would be short-lived. The men are dispirited and their leaders demoralised by the energy Aown by the Government, the loyalty of the tcoftps, and the postponement of the railway strike, which was tin backbone of the move snent.
The city is quiet. Arrests continue to be made. (Hava-)

div.head:
GREECE AND ROMANIA.
ANTI-GREEK DEMONSTRATION IN SOFIA.

div.p: The expulsion of Greeks from Roumania continoes on a large scale. Several thousand persons made an anti Greek demonstration here and attempted to assemble before the Greek Legation, but were dispersed by troops, who fired on them an! wounded several persons. (Reuter)

div.head:
ASIATICS IN THE TRANSVAAL.
PROPOSED LEGISLATION.

div.p: The Government intends to introduce ^legislation regarding the registration of Asiatics, with a view of preventing a, large influx of the latter until a responsible Government baa been established. (Reuter

HOUSE or COMMONS —The Government majority fell to five' in the voting on the Trade- Unions' amendment to the Trade Disputes Bill. Tbe amendment was rejected by 127 votes to 122. The majority included the foremost members of the Opposition and twelve other Unionists. (Heater)
The House of Lords has voted on the second reading of the Education Bill. (Reuter)
Parliament has adjourned until 23rd Ooto- ber. (Reuter
Cockermouth Election.— Mr. Randles, the Unionist candidate, has been elected with 4,593 votes. Mr. Guest, the Liberal candidate, had 3,903 votes and Mr. Smillie, the Labour candidate, 1.436 votes.
Cricket — Surrey brat Sussex by 9 wickets. West Indians beat Yorkshire by 2f2 roDP. Gloucestershire beat Middlesex by 121 ruDS, The match betwren Worcestershire and Hampshire WSB drawn. (Reuter)

div.head: EMIGRANT STEAMER SINKS. OVER 300 PEOPLE DROWNED.

div.p: The Italian steamer Sirio, from Genoa, bonnd tor South Amerioa, with 700 emigrants and a crew of 100 men on board, was wrecked and sank off Cape Palos, near here. It is estimated that 200 people were drowned. The captain committed suicide. (Reuter
. The Italian mail steamer Sirio, with 800 emigrants on board, mostly Italian and Spanish, has sunk off Cape Palos. 385 people were drowned. The captaio committed suicide (Tonal)

div.head: H.M.S. MONTAGU. VESSEL TO BE ABANDONED.

div.p: It hss been definitely decided to abandon the Montagu. All the fittings and valuable artioles on board will be removed. (llmter)

The "Times" urges the Government to take energetic steps in order to avert interference on the part of China with the Customs service which, it says, is a guarantee both for Chinese and foreign trade and the regular service of debt. 1 (Fpyter)
Princta- Albert has given birth to a SOD. IHaval
The Duke of Rutland is dead. (Reuter)

Charles Cecil John Manners, st.G,, Duke of Rutlaud, eldest son of the late duke, was born May 16, 1815, and educated at Eton and Trinity .College, Cambridge. He was honorary Colonel of the Leicestershire Militia, and Lord-Lieuteoant ot that county. As Marquis of Granby he was one of the members in the Conservative interest for Stamford from Aug., 1837, till Jojy, )§52, when he was returned for North Leicestershire, wfcjcfc he continued to represent till he succeeded his father in the dokedom, Jan. 20, 1857. He opposed the Free Trade Measures of Sir Robert Peel in 1845-S. and it ;s understood that the leader ship of the Conservative party in the Lower House was offered to him on the dsatji of Lord 0. Bentinck. He was appointed First Commissioner of the .Office of AVorka with a seatln the Cabinet, and sjiorn a Privy Councillor in Lord Derby's first adminisUation in 185i, held the same post in Lord Derby's second admiDi»tr»tion in 1858-59, and was reappointed in Lord Derby's third administration, If 66 67. On the return ot the Conserva, fives tp officq in Feb, 1874, he was appointed Post m ister-Geueral, and he held that post until the Conservatives vo^t Qqf of office in April, 1880, whan he was oreated a G.C.B. In 1885 he was- returned for the tew Melton Division of I^oioesterahire, and was Postmaster- General in Lord Salisbury's Government. The honorary degree of D.U.L. was conferred upon him by the University of Oxford in ) 876. Pro viously, in 1862, the degree of L.L.D. of Cambridge Uuiversity was conferred on him. His Grace was a staunch defender of cho rights of the Church, a supporter of the agricultural interest, and acted for many years as Chairman of the Tithe Redemption Trust. His first literary peiformauce w is "England's Trust ; and other Poems," 1841. Appended to this volume are some minor pieces, headed "Memorials of other Lands," commemorative of His Grace's excursion, in company with his elder biother, then Marquis of Granby (the late Duke of Rutland) through France, Spain, Switzerland, and Italy. His other works ace : 11A Plea for National Holy-Days," 1843 "Notes of an Irish Tonr," 1849 "Notes of a Cruise in Scotch Watars.on board the Duke of Rutland's Yacht, Resolution, in 18!8," Loud.) 1850, a handsome folio vo'ume embellished with sketches by John Christian Schetky. Esq. ; "English Ballads and other Poems," 1850 ; "The. Faotories Bill, a Speech," 1850 ; 'The Church of England in the Colonies." a leotnre, 1851 ; "The Importance of Literature to Man of Business," one of a series of lectures . 60 entitled, 1852 ."Speech on the Abolition of Church Rates, 1856. In 1886 he was appointed Chancellor of the Dooby of Lancaster in Lord Salisbury's seoond administration. He succeeded to the dukedom on the death of his brother, March 2, 18Q8. His Grice married first, in 1851, Catharine Louisa Georgiana, daughter of the late Colonel Marlay, C.B. (she died April 7, 1854); and secondly, in 1862, Janetta, e'dest ' daughter ol Thomas Hughan, E=q.

div.head: AMAN'S HANDBOOK OF DON'TS.
div.p: i:v A FEMALE PHILOSOPHER.

The other day I ventured to offer a few suggestions for the reading, marking, and inward digestion of a woman with regard to the keeping, when woo, of the love and interest of that most fiokle of all animals - Man. It is a pet theory among men that woman is more incoonstant and more difficult to understand than themselves. There never was a greater delusion. If a man cannot have the woman he oan pat in a very excellent and enjoyable time with a woman, especially if she is pretty and bright, and the woman is for the time forgotten. If a woman cannot have the man, she feels all the time she is with a man how lovely it would be if only it were someone else ! Then, as regards the relative complexity of the two sexes, my experience has taught me that given ten average women and a certain set of oircumstances, nine out of the ten will act in the same way, and you can always forecast what that way will be. But given ten average men and the same set of circumstances, and they will act in ten different ways, and yoa oannot safq'y foretell one of them.
But I am wandering from iny point, which is the other side of the ijaestioq—namely, tfie retention of a woman's love and respect by a man.

This, it most be admitted from the beginning, is a far easier matter. A man has his professjqq or business, his sports, his friends, his olob, and a thousand and one interests which inevitably olaim and divide his attention and affections. A woman as a rule has one centre, one pivot to her life—her one particqlqr iqan, and even if she has h0r Aa4 be? aporta and her other qatgide inters >ts, they form bat a relatively sajsll fraotiqu o^ l)3r life. 2\nd then there is the que ofteq ignqre4 bqt all- powerful factor that should never be fof- gotteq -that qjan is by n%tqrq tlje love? cf bat one—at a time I Bat oqoe again, as in my humble advice to woman, let oq$ repeat that my suggestions are for the or4inary average mixture of good and bad, everyday mem bars of mankind, not for the heartless brute, nor yet for the Galahad whom we all long, and most of as in vain, to meet.
Don't let a woman find you out in a lie.

1 say advisedy, doq't let her fiid yoa out, the alternative, "Ifon't tell fyer a lie,M being possibly beyond the attainment of most. Many women labour undor the illaaion—or shall l 8ay delusion ?—that most meq ^re little tin George Washingtons, and it is'something like dragging one of her beliefs oat by the roots if she disoovers that her man has some of the attributes of Ananias. A woman still retains the idea that a man is a mentally etronger and finer animal than herself, and believes him U above Ji^s,

unless she has a husband who belongs to and constantly visits a club, and then film knows better), and littleness. It is an excellent illusion from your point of view, and it is worth a little trouble to keep np. Woman has more ge^prosity of mind than she is often given oredit for, and you will generally find it pay far better in the end to t^ll fyer th0 troth and appeal to that generosity, than to tell her a comfortable lie if there is the least prospect of yoar being found oat. If a woman ouoe proves that a maq has lied to her, he is never put back on tfie same pin* nacle again. Don't be mean to a vforqan or tq any one iq her pretence.

A woman loathes the niggard in a man as she hates a spot on her nose, even if she has to praotise strict economy herself. Don't be sparing in your tips to a waiter or a oabby if §be is with you. Believe me, if she has not seen thp amount, she will note his reoeption of the same, and by hi 1 manner \y'.ll goe s at thp generosity thereof or the reverse, and judge yoa accordingly. Oce of the unforgivab'e sins a man from a womau's point of view is meanneps or nearness. If you have not the morey to be generous in actuality, be at least generous in thought and tell her how you would like to give her this or that. That will be sufficient for the average good bad wman. Benson propounded one of the greatest principles of a woman's philosophy when, iq ''The Image in the Sand,'1 he makes his heroine say to the maq she loves : "Jf you sent me jast a line saying, *1 saw a diamond tiara at Streeter's this morniup, and wanted to give it you,* that is fast the same to me as if you had given it me. Your thought has given it me. It ia the thought I valae ; the thing itself is only symbol of a thought." Jf you are generous in neither thought nor deed you will never win a woman's loving respect,
Don't make a fool of her or raise a laugh against her before another woman.

If you must make a fool of her, do it before a man and she will take it good-naturedly, even if she does not join in the langh against herself. But if you do it before another womaD, be it servant or friend, she will never forgive you.
Don't refuse to tell her you love her, even if she asks you the question ad nauseam.

You think if you have told a woman you love her that is enough- she ought to have sense enpngh to know when you mean it and to be content and take it on trnst. But it is not enough. A woman oannot be told itr too often. Tell a woman day after day, if she requires it of yon, that you do love her and make bar believe it, and then you can rob her, regleot her, be unfaithful to her, And she will still cling to you and fight for you- in words in polite society, or words and deed in impolite against all the world
Don't ever play second fiddle

To do yo justice you don't often try that, poet in life's orchestra. Be master always. Few women have the honesty to admit it, but in reality they love a master, even if he has a touoh of the brute in his methods. But, to be all-conquering, he should te master with the wilinesa of the serpent as well as the foroe of the brnte. If a m in has sense enough to wind up his brutality with a kiss, he will keep a woman his devoted slave for ever. He may beat her—metaphorically —every day in the week, if she knows that on Sanday there will be the ki?s which will pay for all.
Don't insist on seeing your wife's letters

She may have nothing whatever in her correspondence to conceal, and, if yoa leave her to herself, msy possibly bore yon with reading them all aloud to you. Bat she will certainly respeot yon infinitely more if yon leave her the same liberty with regard to her letters that yea would undoubtedly exact for your own.
Don't let her think she may make friends with impunity with other men

I do not mean be jealous on the least or no provocation, and so make yoar own life as well as hers a burden; but let her think, as a matter of pare policy, that you don't altogether like another man's attention, however innooent. She will be so pleased yon have noticed that another man appreciates her, and so glad that yoa oare sufficiently as to show incipient signs of Jealousy, tfiat yoq rqay do wit^ her as you will. }f yon pretend, or, worse still, if you really don'? nqind fier friendship or flirta- tioq wjth another man, she will be first resent- fal, and then will 1OB6 all respect for yoa for not being sufficiently Saltftq as to keep what yon have gQTt *8 your own property, with all rights vested In yourself.
Last and chiefly, Don't firget the little things of life
To a woman these usually mean more than I than the big. Don't forget the little attention-., "remember to ask affsra headachi, to bring an offering, no matter how trifling^ for a birth.

div.head: PRINCE'S CANDID OPINION.
div.p: After exploring the United States and stadyiDg many institutions, his Highness the Gaekwar of Baroda, accompanied by the Maharanee, embarked at New York on Friday week oq tfie White Star liner Celtio for England, fn most respects the Prince pleased people in Amerioa mightily by expressing admiration for thingn saen and persons met. At the last moment, however, a rash interviewer asked him, "Now, what do yon think cf the American wi.men I" expecting to receive the stereotyped answer that "they are the handsomest, tallest, best proportioned, best-dressed women in the world,11 Qastom almost extorts some such admission, bqt the Maharajah, DDmoved, simply replied.

"I will tell you frankly. The American woman is independent, tack, self-possessed, and yet, though I heard a great deal about her beauty, I failed to see it. Much has been written and mocha 'said regarding the wonderful beauty of your women. This beauty I did not find, though found a pleasing, frank, independent type of womanhood."
All the papers quote the Prince's words, one with the headline 'The Gaekwar is blind."

div.head: AUTOMATIC GAMBLING.
div.p: The New York police lately raided a num her of pablio houses and seized gambling ma ohiues conducted on the penny in the slot priu ciple. The maohines looked like cash registers, and the customer, after dropping in a five-oent coin, simply pressed a little handle. If be ware lucky, a bell rang, and a check was given for amonnts ranging from five cents to a dollar.

A manufacturing syndicate placed the machines in the houses under an impression, which was well grounded occasionally in New York regarding gambling rooms, "that the police conld be easily fixed." Apparently the police refused to be fixed, and a number of the . machines were consequently seized.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905

div.head: Telephone Company of Egypt, Limited.
div.p: CAIRO-ALEXANDRIA TELEPHONE.--Rates as follows P.T. 5 for each 3 minutes, or fraction of 3 minutes; P.T. 10 for over 3 up to 8 minutes communication.

PUBLIC CALL-OFFICES : Cairo, Central Office, Opera Square, and New Bar; Helouan, Central Office, Maison Purvis ; Alexandria, St Mark's Buildings, Egyptian Bar, I. Castelli & Co.; Ramleh, Central Office. San Stefano Casino 30.4.906
